questions.text: All of the following are morphological features of Rheumatic heart disease except:
questions.solution:
Ring Abscess: It is a feature of Infective Endocarditis.

Option A: Aschoff bodies

It is the pathognomic feature of RHD which consists of foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells also plump activated macrophages.

Option B: Anitschkow cells

These plump activated macrophages have abundant cytoplasm and central oval to round nuclei in which chromatin condenses into a central, slender, wavy ribbon. It is also known as caterpillar cells.

Option D: MacCallum plaques

It is a subendocardial lesions, exacerbated by regurgitant jets which induce irregular thickenings called MacCallum plaques present in posterior wall of Left Atrium.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page number. 207.

choices.text: It differentiates viable and non viable tissue

questions.text:
Gross finding of a patient with chest pain reveals:

What is the significance of this?
questions.solution:
• Image shown is a section of a heart which is stained by histochemical stain Triphenyltetrazolium chloride(TTC).
  • TTC is used to stain viable myocardial tissue. Healthy, viable tissue containing active lactate dehydrogenase enzymes will metabolize TTC into a red-colored formazan product.
  • In contrast, areas of myocardial infarction or necrosis will not stain red due to the absence of these enzymes and appears as an unstained pale zone.
  • Thus, option D IS CORRECT.

Gross examination by histochemical stain is not useful to identify inflammation (option A), infiltrating neutrophils (option B) and fibrosis (option C).

Reference: Robbins & Cotran pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page number. 548.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male undergoes an esophago gastroduo denoscopy (EGD) for chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) symptoms. Biopsy specimens from the distal esophagus show:
1. Columnar epithelium with goblet cells
2. Intestinal-type epithelium with villiform architecture
3. Absence of dysplasia

What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of columnar epithelium with goblet cells and intestinal-type epithelium with villiform architecture is characteristic of Barrett's esophagus.

Option B, C, D: The absence of dysplasia indicates that there is no neoplastic transformation.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page number. 761.

questions.text: What is the typical immunohistochemical profile of a GIST?
questions.solution:
GIST: It arises from specialized cells in the digestive tract called Interstitial Cells of Cajal (ICCs), which help regulate digestive processes.

  • CD117 (c-KIT) is typically positive in GISTs.
  • CD34 is often positive in GISTs.

Bland spindle cells seen in microscopy.

  • SMA (smooth muscle actin) is typically negative in GISTs, helping to distinguish them from leiomyomas and leiomyosarcomas.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page number. 779.

questions.text:
A biopsy specimen from a patient with chronic colitis shows:
1. Transmural inflammation with granulomas
2. Ulceration and fissuring of the mucosa

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Transmural inflammation (inflammation extending through all layers of the bowel wall) is characteristic of Crohn's disease.
  • Granulomas are a hallmark of Crohn's disease.

Option A: In ulcerative colitis inflammation is limited to mucosa and granulomas are generally absent.

Options C AND D, infectious colitis and ischemic colitis do not exhibit such microscopic features.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page number. 779.

choices.text: Autosomal dominant type of inheritance pattern
Increased risk of pancreatic, breast and lung cancer

questions.text: All are true about Peutz-Jehger syndrome except:
questions.solution:
The polyps in Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome are typically hamartomatous, not adenomatous, and have a lower risk of cancer compared to adenomatous polyps.

The other (A, B & D) options are all true

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by:

  1. Hamartomatous polyps: Benign growths in the gastrointestinal tract, depicting arborising pattern, particularly in the small intestine, stomach, and colon.
  2. Mucocutaneous melanin deposits: Dark blue or brown spots on the skin, lips, mouth, and genital areas.
  3. Increased cancer risk: Higher risk of developing various cancers, including:
    • Gastrointestinal cancers (stomach, small intestine, colon)
    • Pancreatic cancer
    • Breast cancer
    • Ovarian cancer
    • Testicular cancer
    • Lung cancer
  4. Other features: PJS may also be associated with:
    • Intestinal obstruction or intussusception
    • Anemia
    • Chronic diarrhea
    • Abdominal pain
  5. PJS is caused by mutations in the STK11 (LKB1) gene, which is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.
  6. Management involves regular surveillance, polyp removal, and cancer screening.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page number: 809.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents with:
1. Colonoscopy showing a 3 cm adenocarcinoma in the ascending colon
2. Family history of colon cancer in his father and brother
3. Microsatellite instability (MSI) testing showing high-level MSI

What is the most likely underlying genetic defect?
questions.solution:
High-level MSI is characteristic of HNPCC, which is caused by mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes, including MLH1, MSH2, and MSH6.

  • Any of these genes could be responsible for the underlying genetic defect, and further testing would be needed to determine the specific gene involved.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page number 814.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman presents with:
1. Abdominal pain
2. Nausea and vomiting
3. Elevated liver enzymes

Imaging studies reveal a 3 cm mass in the liver, and biopsy confirms cholangiocarcinoma. She has a history of:
questions.solution:
Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is a chronic liver disease that increases the risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma.

PSC is a progressive, chronic liver disease that causes inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts, both inside and outside the liver.

Bile Duct Damage: The scarring leads to narrowing of the bile ducts, which restricts the flow of bile, eventually causing liver damage and cirrhosis.

Association with IBD: PSC is strongly associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), particularly ulcerative colitis. A significant percentage of PSC patients also have IBD.

Symptoms:

  • Fatigue
  • Itching (pruritus)
  • Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
  • Abdominal pain (especially in the upper right quadrant)
  • Weight loss and fever

Diagnosis: Although the gold standard for the diagnosis of PSC remains endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) / magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP), a liver biopsy can aid in the diagnosis.

Most cases of PSC involve the large intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic bile ducts, which results in a "beads on a string" appearance on ERCP/MRCP.

The most classic findings of PSC include large bile ducts surrounded by concentric fibrosis, which is also referred to as "onion skin" fibrosis

Complications:

  • Liver failure and cirrhosis
  • Increased risk of bile duct cancer (cholangiocarcinoma)
  • Increased risk of liver cancer and gallbladder cancer

Option B: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection is a risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma, but not typically associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

Option C: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease is a risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma, but not typically associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

Option D: Choledochal cyst is a congenital anomaly of the bile ducts, but is not typically associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page number. 859.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents with:
1. Abdominal pain
2. Weight loss
3. Diarrhea

Imaging studies reveal a 1 cm solid lesion in the pancreatic head. Laboratory tests show:
1. Amylase: 150 IU/L
2. Lipase: 200 IU/L
3. Chromogranin A: 500 ng/mL
4. Synaptophysin: positive

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A. The patient's symptoms, such as abdominal pain, weight loss, and diarrhea, are consistent with a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (PNET).

  • The laboratory results, including elevated chromogranin A and positive synaptophysin, are specific markers for PNETs.
  • The imaging findings of a solid lesion in the pancreatic head are also consistent with PNET.

Option B and C (Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma and Ampullary adenocarcinoma) do not show positivity for synaptophysin or elevated chromogranin A.

Option D. Duodenal carcinoid tumor is a possibility, but the location of the lesion in the pancreatic head makes PNET more likely.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page number. 892.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents with Shortness of breath, Fatigue and Swelling in the legs. Autopsy reveals:
1. Cardiac enlargement with thickening of the left ventricular wall
2. Myocardial fibers show disarray
3. Interstitial fibrosis is present

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
C. The patient's symptoms and autopsy findings are consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, a condition characterized by thickening of the heart muscle, leading to impaired cardiac function.

  • The disarray and hypertrophy of myocardial fibers, along with interstitial fibrosis, are hallmarks of this condition.

A. Hypertensive heart disease would typically show more pronounced left ventricular hypertrophy and fibrosis and shows box car nuclei.

B. Dilated cardiomyopathy would show more pronounced chamber dilation and thinning of the heart muscle.

D. Restrictive cardiomyopathy would show more pronounced fibrosis and stiffening of the heart muscle.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page number 573.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female has a gastric biopsy showing:
1. Lymphoid infiltration of lamina propria
2. Germinal center formation
3. Helicobacter pylori positivity

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Lymphoid infiltration of lamina propria: Indicates an abnormal accumulation of lymphocytes in the stomach lining.
  • Germinal center formation: Suggests lymphoid neoplasia or chronic inflammation.
  • Helicobacter pylori positivity: A common cause of chronic gastritis, which can lead to MALT lymphoma.

A. MALT (mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue) lymphoma is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

  • Gastric MALT lymphoma is commonly associated with H. pylori infection.
  • Characterized by lymphoid infiltration and germinal center formation.

B. Follicular lymphoma:

  • Typically involves lymph nodes, not gastric mucosa.
  • Has distinct histological features (follicular architecture).

C. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma:

  • More aggressive, with large cells and high-grade nuclear pleomorphism.
  • Not typically associated with H. pylori.

D. Chronic gastritis:

  • Lacks germinal center formation and lymphoid neoplasia.
  • May show inflammation and mucosal damage.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page number 767.

questions.text: A GIST tumor is most commonly associated with mutations in which gene?
questions.solution:
• Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors (GISTs) are mesenchymal neoplasms that arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal or their precursors.
  • The majority of GISTs harbor activating mutations in the KIT gene (approximately 75-80%) or the PDGFRA gene (approximately 5-10%).
  • These mutations lead to constitutive activation of tyrosine kinases, driving tumor growth and proliferation.

B. KIT gene mutations:

  • Most common mutations occur in exon 11 (70-80%).
  • Other mutations occur in exons 9, 13, and 17.
  • KIT mutations are more common in gastric GISTs.

A. PDGFRA gene mutations:

  • Less common than KIT mutations.
  • Often occur in exon
  • PDGFRA mutations are more common in small intestine

C & D. BRAF and KRAS mutations are not typically associated with GISTs.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran pathologic basics of disease, 10th edition, page number 779.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old athlete undergoes cardiac biopsy due to recurrent ventricular tachycardia. Histopathological examination shows:
1. Fibrofatty replacement of right ventricular myocardium
2. Loss of cardiomyocytes
3. Inflammation

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
C. ARVC is characterized by:

  • Fibrofatty replacement of right ventricular myocardium
  • Loss of cardiomyocytes
  • Inflammation
  • Genetic mutations (e.g., PKP2, DSP, DSG2)
  • Clinical features:
    • Recurrent ventricular tachycardia
    • Syncope
    • Sudden cardiac death
    • Family history

Option A: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

Characteristics:

  1. Thickened ventricular walls (hypertrophy)
  2. Myofiber disarray
  3. Increased collagen deposition
  4. Often genetic (familial)
  • Fibrofatty replacement is not typical in HCM.
  • HCM usually affects the left ventricle.
  • Ventricular tachycardia can occur, but it's less common.

Option B: Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM)

Characteristics:

  1. Dilated ventricles with thinned walls
  2. Reduced contractility
  3. Often caused by:
    • Infections (viral, bacterial)
    • Autoimmune disorders
    • Toxic substances
  • Fibrofatty replacement is not characteristic of DCM.
  • DCM typically affects both ventricles.
  • Ventricular tachycardia can occur, but it's less common.

Option D. Myocarditis

Characteristics:

  1. Inflammation of the myocardium
  2. Often caused by:
    • Viral infections (e.g., Coxsackievirus)
    • Bacterial infections
    • Autoimmune disorders
  3. Can lead to ventricular tachycardia
    • Fibrofatty replacement is not typical in myocarditis.
    • Myocarditis usually affects both ventricles.
    • The clinical presentation and histopathology don't fully align.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page number: 572.

questions.text: A patient with RHD has a histopathological examination showing Valve fibrosis, Chordal rupture, Leaflet thickening. What is the most likely valve affected?
questions.solution:
• Rheumatic Heart Disease (RHD) commonly affects heart valves, particularly those with high pressure and stress.

Mitral Valve

  • Histopathological findings match mitral valve involvement.
  • Most frequently affected valve in RHD.
  • Valve fibrosis and scarring.
  • Chordal rupture and leaflet thickening.
  • Often leads to mitral stenosis and/or regurgitation.

Option B. Aortic Valve

  • Less frequently affected than mitral valve.
  • Typically involves the aortic root and ascending aorta.
  • May show calcification and fibrosis.

Option C. Tricuspid Valve

  • Rarely affected in RHD.
  • Typically involves the tricuspid leaflets and chordae.
  • May show fibrosis and regurgitation.

Option D. Pulmonary Valve

  • Very rarely affected in RHD.
  • Typically involves the pulmonary leaflets and artery.
  • May show fibrosis and stenosis.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page number 562.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy incurs a gunshot wound to the abdomen in a drive-by shooting. At exploratory laparotomy, the surgeon finds a perforated portion of jejunum. She resects this portion and palpates a mass in the jejunal submucosa. Sectioning of this lesion reveals that it is a 1.5-cm diameter circumscribed, solid, tan mass. The mass is sent for frozen section. What is the pathologist most likely to see under her microscope?
questions.solution:
D. This incidental finding is consistent with ectopic pancreas, which can be found in the bowel in 2% of individuals.

  • It may be found within a Meckel diverticulum, although in this case no diverticulum was found, and such a diverticulum is found in the ileum as a vitelline duct remnant.

Option A: Adenocarcinoma is unlikely in a boy in his teens, and adenocarcinoma of the small intestine is rare.

Option B: Ectopic gastric mucosa is most often found within a Meckel diverticulum.

Option C: Non-Hodgkin lymphomas of the bowel produce larger masses and are usually seen in older individuals.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran pathologic basics of disease, 10th Edition, Page number 881.
